option.name: title_text
option.value: Introduction to Billing and Accounts Receivable in AggieEnterprise

string_table.name: pxabnsnfns11111111101
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To preview this video, use the Preview functionality in Storyline, republish your course using standard MP4 video, or publish to Review 360.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Lesson one: Getting started" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Lesson two: Receivables Workflows" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Help us improve this course by completing this quick 5-question survey." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Thank you for your participation. Click the Exit button to complete this course. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Lesson 3: Introduction to AggieEnterprise Receivables Subledger" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Lesson four: Receivables reports" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

terms.term: Denotes a note to reduce the balance of invoices when payment is received from customer against an open transaction by UC Davis.

The local Chart of Accounts developed by UC Davis aligns with UCOPs Common Chart of Accounts to establish consistency in UC accounting system and practices. The chart is comprised of defined segments and values to provide the foundation for recording and reporting financial transactions at UC Davis.
The combination of chart segment values for recording financial transactions.
Rules configured in Oracle to define whether a specific value in one chart segment can be combined with specific values in other segments.
Customers who fail to make payments as agreed or when due.
An invoice which is overdue for payment from the customer.
A ledger which stores, sorts and organizes summary financial data used to support financial reporting.
The reporting tree structure that defines the relationship between the values in each chart segment.
An itemized bill from a supplier representing an amount due for goods supplied or services rendered.

Allows you to increase or decrease the amount due from the customer. An adjustment is made directly to the original customer transaction. This includes credit adjustment, write-off, and invoice reversal.
An item code is a representation of a product or service provided by UC Davis to a customer and is linked to the corresponding COA.
POET is an acronym for a chart string that is specific to the PPM subledger. The POET string maps to Chart of Accounts segments.

Denotes the method used to link the bank account where cash is received into Oracle Financials receipt document. The five methods at UC Davis include: lockbox, cashiers, ACH, credit card and transfers

One of the components of the Chart of Accounts which, when combined with other segments, tells the unique story of each individual transaction. Each segment has a defined value set and hierarchy. Example segments are the Natural Account and Financial Department.
A ledger, which captures detailed transactional information for a sub-set of transactions such as accounts receivable.
Denotes the payments received from known customers, which are yet to be applied to a transaction.
Denotes the payments received from unknown customers, which are yet to be applied to a transaction.
A unique combination of numeric or alpha-numeric characters, which is specific to a segment.
A group of values that expresses the function of a Chart of Accounts segment.
